page.title: 11NATURAL HISTORY
page.content: {Mill Hill Crossroads}(Ref:306396) was chosen for its beauty. The small copse on the S.W. corner has 5 types of tree and each spring is aglow with snowdrops and daffodils planted by a local farmer for the pleasure of passers by.{The Craile Eau}stream runs here bordering both Frampton and Kirton. Only young elm trees survive here, the others being replaced in 1984 with other varieties due to disease. This is also true of old ash trees along the road to Boston. {Multon Ings/Badger Lane}(293405) few trees and hedges in these lanes which are used mainly as field access. They are typical of our area and maintain a variety of ecology along their margins. 45 wild flowers, 11 grasses, 7 types of butterfly, 3 of tree, 30 of birds and 10 animals were noted in 1985, despite crop spraying.
